articles.headline: Strapped Pension Funds, and the Hefty Investment Fees They Pay
articles.snippet: By investing in private equity and hedge funds, pension overseers pay money to Wall Street that should be going to retirees.
articles.abstract: By investing in private equity and hedge funds, pension overseers pay money to Wall Street that should be going to retirees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where are the pensioners’ yachts?

articles.headline: New Gene Tests Pose a Threat to Insurers
articles.snippet: Many consumers will soon have a better sense of their risk for Alzheimer’s and other debilitating conditions. Insurers will have no way of knowing.
articles.abstract: Many consumers will soon have a better sense of their risk for Alzheimer’s and other debilitating conditions. Insurers will have no way of knowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pat Reilly had good reason to worry about Alzheimer’s disease: Her mother had it, and she saw firsthand the havoc it could wreak on a family, much of it financial.

articles.headline: For-Profit Charlotte Law School Is Subject of North Carolina Inquiry
articles.snippet: Charlotte School of Law, already struggling to remain open and fighting lawsuits filed by former students, faces a civil investigation by the state’s attorney general.
articles.abstract: Charlotte School of Law, already struggling to remain open and fighting lawsuits filed by former students, faces a civil investigation by the state’s attorney general.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it battles to stay open, Charlotte School of Law is blaming its problems on the federal government, the law school accreditation body and disgruntled former students who have sued the school.

articles.headline: Sinclair Requires TV Stations to Air Segments That Tilt to the Right
articles.snippet: Journalists at KOMO broadcast station in Seattle, which was acquired by Sinclair Broadcast Group in 2013, have chafed at programming directives.
articles.abstract: Journalists at KOMO broadcast station in Seattle, which was acquired by Sinclair Broadcast Group in 2013, have chafed at programming directives.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are called “must-runs,” and they arrive every day at television stations owned by the Sinclair Broadcast Group — short video segments that are centrally produced by the company. Station managers around the country are directed to work them into the broadcast over a period of 24 or 48 hours.

articles.headline: How Google Took Over the Classroom
articles.snippet: The tech giant is transforming public education with low-cost laptops and free apps. But schools may be giving Google more than they are getting.
articles.abstract: The tech giant is transforming public education with low-cost laptops and free apps. But schools may be giving Google more than they are getting.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The sixth graders at Newton Bateman, a public elementary school here with a classic red brick facade, know the Google drill.

articles.headline: How Noncompete Clauses Keep Workers Locked In
articles.snippet: Restrictions once limited to executives are now spreading across the labor landscape — making it tougher for Americans to get a raise.
articles.abstract: Restrictions once limited to executives are now spreading across the labor landscape — making it tougher for Americans to get a raise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Keith Bollinger’s paycheck as a factory manager had shriveled after the 2008 financial crisis, but then he got a chance to pull himself out of recession’s hole. A rival textile company offered him a better job — and a big raise.

articles.headline: The Gender Pay Gap Is Largely Because of Motherhood
articles.snippet: Some women work just as much after having children, but employers pay them less, too, assuming they will be less committed, research shows.
articles.abstract: Some women work just as much after having children, but employers pay them less, too, assuming they will be less committed, research shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: When men and women finish school and start working, they’re paid pretty much equally. But a gender pay gap soon appears, and it grows significantly over the next two decades.

articles.headline: Richard Burr Leads Russia Inquiry, Whether He Likes It or Not
articles.snippet: Mr. Burr, the unobtrusive chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, is moving into a spotlight he never expected and does not seem to relish.
articles.abstract: Mr. Burr, the unobtrusive chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, is moving into a spotlight he never expected and does not seem to relish.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The premonition came in a Winston-Salem conference room, on an otherwise happy election night in 2004, before Richard M. Burr of North Carolina had even declared victory in his bid to join the Senate.

articles.headline: Behind China’s $1 Trillion Plan to Shake Up the Economic Order
articles.snippet: In stark contrast to President Trump’s “America First” mantra, the “One Belt, One Road” plan aims to remake global commerce in China’s image.
articles.abstract: In stark contrast to President Trump’s “America First” mantra, the “One Belt, One Road” plan aims to remake global commerce in China’s image.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANG VIENG, Laos — Along the jungle-covered mountains of Laos, squads of Chinese engineers are drilling hundreds of tunnels and bridges to support a 260-mile railway, a $6 billion project that will eventually connect eight Asian countries.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Yufan Huang

articles.headline: The Election Is Over, but Trump Can’t Seem to Get Past It
articles.snippet: At the root of Donald J. Trump’s unpredictable presidency is a deep frustration about attacks on his legitimacy, and a worry that Washington does not see him as he sees himself.
articles.abstract: At the root of Donald J. Trump’s unpredictable presidency is a deep frustration about attacks on his legitimacy, and a worry that Washington does not see him as he sees himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the small dining room next to the Oval Office where he works much of the time, President Trump keeps a stack of color-coded maps of the United States representing the results of the 2016 election. The counties he won are blotchy red and span most of the nation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: With New Digital Tools, Even Nonexperts Can Wage Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The ransomware tactic behind a global cyberattack on Friday was nothing new. But new digital tools mean that hackers “don’t even need to have any skills to do this anymore.”
articles.abstract: The ransomware tactic behind a global cyberattack on Friday was nothing new. But new digital tools mean that hackers “don’t even need to have any skills to do this anymore.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers are discovering that it is far more profitable to hold your data hostage than it is to steal it.

articles.headline: Real Estate’s New Normal: Homeowners Staying Put
articles.snippet: Low interest rates helped millions buy homes after the recession. With rates rising, many feel locked in, with little upside to moving.
articles.abstract: Low interest rates helped millions buy homes after the recession. With rates rising, many feel locked in, with little upside to moving.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of last year, Greg Rubin was looking to buy a bigger house. He has been in the same two-bedroom home for 17 years and hoped to upgrade to a place with a guest room, a home office and a workshop for his guitars, radio-controlled planes and gardening equipment.

articles.headline: Ransomware’s Aftershocks Feared as U.S. Warns of Complexity
articles.snippet: The effects of a global cyberattack could be magnified as workers return to their offices. President Trump has ordered his homeland security adviser to coordinate a response.
articles.abstract: The effects of a global cyberattack could be magnified as workers return to their offices. President Trump has ordered his homeland security adviser to coordinate a response.
articles.lead_paragraph: The components of the global cyberattack that seized hundreds of thousands of computer systems last week may be more complex than originally believed, a Trump administration official said Sunday, and experts warned that the effects of the malicious software could linger for some time.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Sewell Chan and Mark Scott

articles.headline: U.S. Firms Want In on China’s Global ‘One Belt, One Road’ Spending
articles.snippet: General Electric, Citibank and Honeywell are among companies angling for potentially big business, but foreign firms must contend with Chinese rivals.
articles.abstract: General Electric, Citibank and Honeywell are among companies angling for potentially big business, but foreign firms must contend with Chinese rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: XUZHOU, China — As China plans to build a raft of roads, rail lines, ports and airports across Asia, Africa and Europe, skeptics say Chinese companies will be the only real winners from the ambitious initiative.

articles.headline: A Network Ad Wrangler Undaunted by Facebook and Google
articles.snippet: Linda Yaccarino, the head of advertising sales for NBCUniversal, has reoriented herself to take on even online behemoths.
articles.abstract: Linda Yaccarino, the head of advertising sales for NBCUniversal, has reoriented herself to take on even online behemoths.
articles.lead_paragraph: After completing her first year as the head of advertising sales for NBCUniversal, Linda Yaccarino went out to dinner with her husband to celebrate.

articles.headline: As Viewers Drift Online, Advertisers Hold Fast to Broadcast TV
articles.snippet: Ad buyers will spend billions, as they did last year, to be a part of the TV season, knowing that, ratings aside, television still reaches more people than digital ads.
articles.abstract: Ad buyers will spend billions, as they did last year, to be a part of the TV season, knowing that, ratings aside, television still reaches more people than digital ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: TV ratings are collapsing. Media stocks are falling. Cord cutting is accelerating.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senators Pull Away From Trump, Alarmed at His Volatility
articles.snippet: The lawmakers are showing increasing signs of separating from the president to pursue a more traditional conservative agenda and protect their political futures.
articles.abstract: The lawmakers are showing increasing signs of separating from the president to pursue a more traditional conservative agenda and protect their political futures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, increasingly unnerved by President Trump’s volatility and unpopularity, are starting to show signs of breaking away from him as they try to forge a more traditional Republican agenda and protect their political fortunes.

articles.headline: Politics, It Seems, Has Jolted Even the Idiot Box Awake
articles.snippet: Critics credit shows like “The Handmaid’s Tale” and comedians like Stephen Colbert for dealing with issues that resonate today. Viewers, it seems, want shows that are “woke.”
articles.abstract: Critics credit shows like “The Handmaid’s Tale” and comedians like Stephen Colbert for dealing with issues that resonate today. Viewers, it seems, want shows that are “woke.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Idiot Box is wising up. But is it waking up?

articles.headline: Lyft and Waymo Reach Deal to Collaborate on Self-Driving Cars
articles.snippet: The fiercely competitive autonomous vehicle market got a jolt when Lyft, the ride-hailing start-up, and Waymo, the self-driving unit of Google’s parent company, confirmed a partnership.
articles.abstract: The fiercely competitive autonomous vehicle market got a jolt when Lyft, the ride-hailing start-up, and Waymo, the self-driving unit of Google’s parent company, confirmed a partnership.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As the race to bring self-driving vehicles to the public intensifies, two of Silicon Valley’s most prominent players are teaming up.

articles.headline: Iranian Voter’s Plea: Stop Saying ‘Death to America’
articles.snippet: Few in Iran, where roughly 8 million are unemployed, are optimistic that Friday’s presidential election will help end a cycle of poverty and turn around the economy.
articles.abstract: Few in Iran, where roughly 8 million are unemployed, are optimistic that Friday’s presidential election will help end a cycle of poverty and turn around the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — As a college student studying mechanics, Hamidreza Faraji had expected after graduation to land a steady job with a fixed salary, a pension plan and the occasional bonus. He envisioned coming home at 6 p.m. to his family and vacationing at a resort on the Caspian Sea.

articles.headline: As Their Clout Wanes, Saudi Arabia and Russia Extend Oil Production Cuts
articles.snippet: The announcement by the world’s two biggest oil exporters means the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is likely to follow suit next week.
articles.abstract: The announcement by the world’s two biggest oil exporters means the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is likely to follow suit next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: With oil markets flagging, the world’s two biggest oil exporters agreed on Monday to extend production cuts for several months, sending the price of crude soaring.

articles.headline: Strict North Carolina Voter ID Law Thwarted After Supreme Court Rejects Case
articles.snippet: The move leaves in place a lower-court ruling that struck down key parts of the law as an unconstitutional effort to target African-Americans.
articles.abstract: The move leaves in place a lower-court ruling that struck down key parts of the law as an unconstitutional effort to target African-Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to revive a restrictive North Carolina voting law that a federal appeals court had struck down as an unconstitutional effort to “target African-Americans with almost surgical precision.”
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Uber Engineer Barred From Work on Key Self-Driving Technology, Judge Says
articles.snippet: Uber sidestepped a full shutdown of its self-driving car efforts when a judge stopped short of issuing a temporary injunction against the company’s autonomous vehicle program.
articles.abstract: Uber sidestepped a full shutdown of its self-driving car efforts when a judge stopped short of issuing a temporary injunction against the company’s autonomous vehicle program.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber, the ride-hailing company, sidestepped a full shutdown of its self-driving car efforts on Monday when a federal judge stopped short of issuing a temporary injunction against the program.
